question: How does a company's stock tanking affect the mood of employees and investors?
contexts:
['ning problem. Or rather, a “not winning” problem.
The typical case is a company that used to be a hot growth com-
pany, but the growth has Yattened out, causing the stock to tank
and everyone to be in a bad mood. Or, alternately, an older
big company that did really well for a while but more recently
hasn’t been doing so well, causing the stock to tank and every-
one to be in a bad mood.
In other words, a company in transition — from winning at one
point, to not winning now.']
ground_truth: The stock tanking of a company can lead to a negative mood among employees and investors. This is often seen in companies that were previously performing well but have experienced a decline in growth, causing the stock to plummet. The resulting bad mood can be attributed to the disappointment and uncertainty surrounding the company's future prospects.

question: What are some of the challenges faced by startups in establishing necessary systems and routines for success?
contexts:
['structure that any established company has.
In a startup it is very easy for the code to not get written, for the
user interfaces to not get designed… for people to not come into
work… and for the wastebaskets to not get emptied.
You as the founder have to put all of these systems and routines
and habits in place and get everyone actually rowing — forget
even about rowing in the right direction: just rowing at all is
hard enough at the start.
And until you do, absolutely nothing happens.
Unless, of course, you do it yourself.
Have fun emptying those wastebaskets.']
ground_truth: In a startup, it is easy for the code to not get written, user interfaces to not get designed, people to not come into work, and wastebaskets to not get emptied. The founder must establish systems, routines, and habits to ensure everyone is working together towards a common goal. Without these in place, nothing will happen unless the founder takes on all tasks themselves.

question: What is the significance of having a large market in the context of online businesses in 2007?
contexts:
['billion people online now. That is a very large market — a lot
of people, spending a lot of time, buying a lot of things, in
totally new ways at the same time as they are abandoning older
services like newspapers, magazines, television, movie theaters,
and print catalogs.
So, my view is that to call a bubble, you have to Xnd evidence of
it outside of the mainstream of the kinds of Internet businesses
that are being built, sold, and run in 2007.
In closing, I’d be the last person to say that I never roll my eyes
at the next startup that’s doing online wiki-based popularity-']
ground_truth: Having a large market in the context of online businesses in 2007 is significant because it represents a vast number of people spending a significant amount of time and money in new ways, while also moving away from traditional services like newspapers, magazines, television, and print catalogs. This shift indicates a changing landscape where online businesses have the potential to thrive and succeed.

question: How can you raise angel money for your startup before you've raised any funds?
contexts:
['This obviously raises the issue of how you’re supposed to do
that before you’ve raised money.
Try to raise angel money, or bootstrap oW of initial customers
or consulting contracts, or work on it aaer hours while keeping
your current job, or quit your job and live oW of credit cards for
a while.
Lots of entrepreneurs have done these things and succeeded —
and of course, many have failed.
Nobody said this would be easy.
The most valuable thing you can do is actually build your prod-
uct. When in doubt, focus on that.
The next most valuable thing you can do is get customers — or,']
ground_truth: Try to raise angel money, or bootstrap off of initial customers or consulting contracts, or work on it after hours while keeping your current job, or quit your job and live off of credit cards for a while.

question: How does Google generate revenue from real advertisers and users?
contexts:
['lot of money quite quickly.
People laughed when Fox bought MySpace for $580 million, but
that’s a business that will generate nearly $300 million in rev-
enue in 2007, and more in 2008.
As an independent asset today, MySpace would probably be val-
ued at between $3 billion and $5 billion today — perhaps higher.
Call that the deal of the decade.
Similarly, Facebook is bringing in a lot more revenue than peo-
ple think.
And then there’s Google.
These companies aren’t pulling in all that revenue via some
kind of Ponzi scheme.
This is money coming from real advertisers and real users for']
ground_truth: Google generates revenue from real advertisers and users through legitimate means, not through a Ponzi scheme. The money comes from actual advertising transactions and user interactions with the platform.

question: How can CEO's identify and promote strong, sharp, aggressive, and ambitious director- or VP-level managers within their company?
contexts:
['strong, sharp, aggressive, ambitious director- or VP-level man-
agers who want to succeed and want your company to succeed.
And promote them, and put them in sole charge of clearly iden-
tiXed teams and missions. (And give them big ol’ fresh option
packages.)
As CEO, you should only have at most one executive between
you and these 20 or 30 up and comers once you are done pro-
moting them and putting them in charge of their teams and
missions.
If you don’t know who those top 20 or 30 up and comers are, if
you don’t promote them, if you don’t put them clearly in charge']
ground_truth: CEOs can identify and promote strong, sharp, aggressive, and ambitious director- or VP-level managers within their company by putting them in sole charge of clearly identified teams and missions, and providing them with significant option packages. The CEO should have at most one executive between them and these up-and-coming managers once they have been promoted and put in charge. It is crucial for CEOs to know who the top 20 or 30 up-and-coming managers are, promote them, and clearly assign them leadership roles within the organization.

question: What does it mean to become a "double threat" in terms of combining undergraduate and graduate degrees?
contexts:
['workforce in a high-impact way when you graduate, and you’ll
have to go get a useful graduate degree.
And even if you are already planning to get a useful graduate
degree, you are much better oW combining it with a substantive
undergraduate degree — thereby becoming a “double threat”.
More on this in a bit.
Which undergraduate degrees are useful in
the real world?
Typically, those that have a technical element of some form —
that teach you how to do something substantive.
Engineering degrees obviously qualify. The current myth that
engineering and computer science degrees are less useful']
ground_truth: The concept of becoming a "double threat" involves combining a substantive undergraduate degree with a useful graduate degree. This combination enhances your impact in the workforce and increases your value by having expertise in both areas.

question: How does the concept of inconsistency-avoidance tendency relate to the persistence of bad habits in individuals?
contexts:
['Five: Inconsistency-Avoidance Tendency
[People are] reluctant to change, which is a form of inconsistency
avoidance. We see this in all human habits, constructive and
destructive. Few people can list a lot of bad habits that they have
eliminated, and some people cannot identify even one of these.
Instead, practically every one has a great many bad habits he has
long maintained despite their being known as bad. Given this sit-
uation, it is not too much in many cases to appraise early-formed
habits as destiny. When Marley’s miserable ghost says, “I wear the', 'new ideas were not accepted because they were inconsistent with
old ideas in place…
We have no less an authority for this than Max Planck, Nobel lau-
reate, Xnder of “Planck’s constant.” Planck is famous not only for
his science but also for saying that even in physics the radically
new ideas are seldom really accepted by the old guard. Instead, said
Planck, the progress is made by a new generation that comes along,
less brain-blocked by its previous conclusions…
One corollary of Inconsistency-Avoidance Tendency is that a per-
son making big sacriXces in the course of assuming a new identity']
ground_truth: The concept of inconsistency-avoidance tendency relates to the persistence of bad habits in individuals as people are reluctant to change, even when they are aware that their habits are destructive. This tendency leads individuals to maintain bad habits that they have long known to be harmful, as changing these habits would introduce inconsistency in their behavior. Therefore, many individuals continue to uphold these bad habits, viewing them almost as destiny.

question: How does inconsistency-avoidance affect human habits and new ideas?
contexts:
['Five: Inconsistency-Avoidance Tendency
[People are] reluctant to change, which is a form of inconsistency
avoidance. We see this in all human habits, constructive and
destructive. Few people can list a lot of bad habits that they have
eliminated, and some people cannot identify even one of these.
Instead, practically every one has a great many bad habits he has
long maintained despite their being known as bad. Given this sit-
uation, it is not too much in many cases to appraise early-formed
habits as destiny. When Marley’s miserable ghost says, “I wear the', 'new ideas were not accepted because they were inconsistent with
old ideas in place…
We have no less an authority for this than Max Planck, Nobel lau-
reate, Xnder of “Planck’s constant.” Planck is famous not only for
his science but also for saying that even in physics the radically
new ideas are seldom really accepted by the old guard. Instead, said
Planck, the progress is made by a new generation that comes along,
less brain-blocked by its previous conclusions…
One corollary of Inconsistency-Avoidance Tendency is that a per-
son making big sacriXces in the course of assuming a new identity']
ground_truth: Inconsistency-Avoidance Tendency affects human habits by making people reluctant to change, even when they are aware of bad habits. This tendency leads individuals to maintain long-standing bad habits despite knowing they are detrimental. It also influences the acceptance of new ideas, as old ideas are often clung to due to inconsistency avoidance. Max Planck noted that even in physics, new ideas are rarely accepted by the old guard, with progress usually made by a new generation less constrained by previous conclusions.

question: How does doubt-avoidance influence quick decision-making and survival instincts in threatening situations?
contexts:
['Four: Doubt-Avoidance Tendency
The brain of man is programmed with a tendency to quickly
remove doubt by reaching some decision.
It is easy to see how evolution would make animals, over the eons,
dria toward such quick elimination of doubt. Aaer all, the one
thing that is surely counterproductive for a prey animal that is
threatened by a predator is to take a long time in deciding what to
do…
So pronounced is the tendency in man to quickly remove doubt
by reaching some decision that behavior to counter the tendency is
required from judges and jurors. Here, delay before decision mak-']
ground_truth: Doubt-avoidance tendency influences quick decision-making and survival instincts in threatening situations by programming the brain to swiftly eliminate doubt and reach a decision. This tendency is evolutionarily advantageous for prey animals facing predators, as taking too long to decide can be counterproductive. Judges and jurors need to counter this tendency to ensure fair decision-making.

question: Why is geographic proximity still important for accessing top companies, individuals, and opportunities in the digital age?
contexts:
['is a mistake. A lot of people — those who don’t live in that place
— don’t want to hear it. But it’s true. Geographic locality is still
— even in the age of the Internet — critically important if you
want to maximize your access to the best companies, the best
people, and the best opportunities. You can always cite exceptions,
but that’s what they are: exceptions.
No one cares who the top Xlmmaker in Chicago is — hell, peo-
ple oaen don’t even care who the top Xlmmaker in New York is,
and quite a lot of Xlms get made out of New York. On the other']
ground_truth: Geographic proximity remains important for accessing top companies, individuals, and opportunities in the digital age because it allows for better access to the best companies, people, and opportunities. Despite the advancements of the Internet, being physically close to key locations can still provide advantages in networking, collaboration, and seizing opportunities that may not be as easily accessible remotely.

Prague, or Macau.']
ground_truth: Los Angeles is considered the entertainment industry hub in the US for growth and change.

question: How does persistence and adaptability affect an entrepreneur's response to doubts and challenges?
contexts:
['some combination of (1) puzzlement and (2) stress.
This is probably a good one for entrepreneurs. You’d better not
have a lot of doubts about what you are doing because everyone
else will, and if you do too, you’ll probably give up.
Of course, an entrepreneur’s doubt avoidance is only a plus
right up to the point where it becomes pigheaded stubbornness
that interferes with her ability to see reality, particularly when a
strategy is not working.
In my view, entrepreneurial judgment is the ability to tell the
diWerence between a situation that’s not working but persistence']
ground_truth: Persistence is crucial for entrepreneurs as it helps them push through doubts and challenges without giving up easily. However, persistence should be balanced with adaptability to recognize when a strategy is not working and make necessary changes. Too much persistence without adaptability can lead to stubbornness and hinder the entrepreneur's ability to see reality.
